Sequence Information.Peptide Name: LL-23 (LL23, fragment of LL-37, cathelicidin; natural AMPs; UCLL1; humans;  primates, mammals, animals)

Literature Information.Literature: A natural  innate immune peptide corresponding to the N-terminal 23 residues of human LL-37.host protease cleavage:  Protease-cleaved product of LL-37 in human skin. The active fragment appeared to be short-lived in vitro since it reduced with time and became not detectable after 24 h.Structure: Its structure and dynamics have been characterized in membrane-mimetic models (SDS, DPC, and D8PG) using both unlabeled and 15N-labeled samples (Biochemistry 2012).You can rotate, zoom, and view the 3D structure bound to SDS micellesherein the PDB. The Ser9 site splits the hydrophobic surface of the amphipathic helix into two domains, which explains its poor antimicrobial activity. A change of S9 to a hydrophobic A or V as observed in other homologous sequences revealed a deeper penetration into micelles (rather than helical strucure per se) is responsible for increased antibacterial activity.Activity: Active against only susceptible bacterial S. aureus mprF (KO) (diffusion assay), E. coli DC2 with altered outer membrane (MIC 9 uM) but weakly against E.coli K12 (MIC 160 uM). Based on the 3D structure, however, a mutation of Ser9 with either Ala or Val modulates the activities of LL-23. The Ser9Val mutant can better penetrate into membranes, leading to improved antibacterial activity.Recombinant production:bacteria:Escherichia coli: a bacterial expression system has been established for this peptide (Li etal., 2007). Its yeild is higher than other LL-37 cleaved more active peptides, indicating the more active AMPs can interfere with peptide expression.APD update 7/2012; 12/2012; 7/2021; 4/2023
Literature Information.Author: Yamasaki K, Schauber J, Coda A, Lin H, Dorschner RA, Schechter NM, Bonnart C, Descargues P, Hovnanian A, Gallo RL.2006
Literature Information.Title: Kallikrein-mediated proteolysis regulates the antimicrobial effects of cathelicidins in skin
